Using Python for Statistics

Checkpoints on this Page:

  • Checkpoint 1: Calculating Group Mean Nitrate
  • Checkpoint 2: Import Class Data
  • Checkpoint 3: Calculate Means for Class Data
  • Checkpoint 4: Calculate Medians for Class Data
  • Checkpoint 5: Calculate Ranges for Class Data
  • Checkpoint 6: Calculate Standard Deviations for Class Data

As you might have guessed, Python can do much more than just the functions len(), min(), and max(). In fact, it can help us calculate our measures of center!

You have already calculated the mean and median by hand on your lab sheet. Now, let‚Äôs ask Python to do it!

Measures of Center With Python

Mean

Python has built-in tools to calculate the mean. We‚Äôll use something called NumPy (Numerical Python). NumPy is one example of a library or package that you can add to Python. When you add a library to Python, you are increasing the functions availble to you. For example, we have many more options with NumPy than just len(), min(), and max().

We have to ‚Äúimport‚Äù these libraries in Python and then often give them a nickname. For example, we import NumPy as np instead of typing ‚Äúnumpy‚Äù all the time. An example of how this work has been written (and already run) below.

Breaking it down:
- import numpy as np = Load the NumPy library/package (we only do this once per file/page)
- np.mean() = NumPy‚Äôs function to calculate mean

Your Turn: Calculate Your Group‚Äôs Mean Nitrate

The website doesn‚Äôt save your nitrate readings list from the previous page, so you‚Äôll need to re-enter your data into the list below (Line 3) again.

Class Data
One of the benefits of using Python is that is can handle much larger amount amounts of data with ease. For example, let‚Äôs consider the nitrate and nitrite data your whole class collected. We‚Äôll do that by importing the data collected in the Google Form. That form sends the data to a spreadsheet, or CSV (comman separated values) file.

Measures of Spread with Python

Today, we‚Äôll discuss two measures of spread: the range and the standard deviation.

Range

The range is a fairly simple calculation. It‚Äôs the biggest number minus the smallest number. Or, put differently, the maximum minus the minimum in a dataset.

max() - min()

Here is an example of finding the range using our sample dataset:

Standard Deviation

The standard deviation tells us how spread out the numbers are from the mean. Put diffently, it tells us the average distance the data in the dataset is from the mean. The formula looks a bit technical:

Here is an example of calculating the standard deviation using our sample dataset:

What Could Cause High Variability?

If a creek‚Äôs reading has high standard deviation (lots of variability in comparison to other creeks), it might mean:

  1. Pollution events - A factory dumps waste occasionally
  2. Storm runoff - Rain washes fertilizer from farms into the creek
  3. Natural cycles - Some creeks naturally vary
  4. Sensor problems - The equipment might need calibration
  5. Different sampling times - Morning vs afternoon can be different

It might also signal that your data has one or more outliers. We‚Äôll talk more about outliers on the next page.

Quick Reference: Python Functions

Function What It Does Example
np.mean() Calculates average np.mean([7.1, 7.2, 7.3]) = 7.2
np.median() Calculates median np.median([7.1, 7.2, 7.3]) = 7.2
np.std() Calculates standard deviation np.std([7.1, 7.2, 7.3]) = 0.3
len() Counts items len([1, 2, 3]) = 3
max() Finds maximum max([1, 2, 3]) = 3
min() Finds minimum min([1, 2, 3]) = 1
